reviewText: The Dachshund is SO CUTE.. Plot, not so much... Predictable, but about what I expected.  Perfect for wiener lovers out there.

This is the story of a family in pain who adopt a little wiener dog they name Shelly.  By focusing on Shelly,  the family dynamic starts to improve. The movie got off to a rocky start.  It was clear that this was a low budget effort but, if you can get past a few hiccups then you might just discover that it's actually a very enjoyable little gem.

This movie had a kickstarter campaign for 10K and backing from a west coast franchise called Wienerschnitzel.  Some reviewers took exception to this but it doesn't detract from the story in the least.  In fact, I thought it made perfect sense since Wienerschnitzel really does sponsor the event that the movie depicts.  This is a cute, enjoyable, genuine G-rated movie that the family will enjoy.

Cute family fare about a boy missing his recently dead mom and how dad, little sister and teenage brother are coping. He finds a picture of his mom as a little girl holding a wiener dog and a trophy. His dad explains that his mom won the Wiener Dog races as a kid. He is inspired, and adopts a tiny Wiener dog, with a strange birthmark. A mysterious lady, played by Morgan Fairchild, is interested in the dog. Since I love and own dachshunds, I loved this movie. It is great to watch with kids, lots of fun. Nothing heavy or deep.

Weak plot, weak script, weak acting and surprisingly not that many wiener dogs!
I mentioned to my wife that it seemed like a crowdfunded movie and sure enough at the end it stated that it was originally started from a kickstarter campaign.
The oldest son scowled and 'played' the guitar, the younger son seemed to be all hair, and the young daughter's screaming became almost unbearable as the movie wore on.
The most disappointing part was the scarcity of actual wiener dogs and wiener dog racing during the movie.
Then of course there was the fact that it showed the star wiener dog injured holding up a front paw only to later have them bandage a rear paw.
Someone obviously told Morgan Fairchild to play it as Cruela De Vil but even that was not fleshed out properly... and even the way she cheated was so unbelievable that it defies explanation.
The worst indignity was that they used 'stand-in' wiener dogs that did not even look close to the ones they were standing in for.
Came in expecting very little... and still left disappointed. My wife took away my movie choosing privileges for a week after this movie :-)

Ok, I hate to give something a bad rating BUT UUUUUG as Charlie Brown would say. I have a wiener dog and was excited when I came across this movie. So my famille sat down for a movie night and stared watching. We could not get half way through. It was so poorly written, and the acting was well terrible. The plot of the story is the mother has died recently and one of the kids finds a picture of his mother when she was a child with a Doxie that had won a race. The child has a birthday and he won't a dog like his mother had. So they rescue him one and a rich woman immediately wont's to buy the dog. The movie must have been finance by a fast food chain Wienershnitzel because they are constantly in the restaurant. The father also gets fired from his job working in a gym and replaced by a guy who has a spray that makes you grow muscles without working out. Right? The dog also gets hurt and is holding up her front right leg but they take her to the girls house that signed them up for the race and she raps the back leg. And the father is instantly in love with the girl. We just could not finish watching it. I wish I had not wasted my money on it.

I'm a dog lover (mom to 3 dogs) and pet blogger.  I'm all dog, all the time, but the one thing I cannot stand (besides images of abused animals) are movies with dogs.  At some point a dog is abused or dies and although I know it's all fake, it sticks with me.  I sat down to Watch Wiener Dog Nationals one afternoon when I had nothing else to do and needed to relax and get my head out of my computer (so I watched TV instead).

Wiener Dog Nationals was a total surprise to me.  As I was watching it, I grabbed my phone to post that I was watching a terrible movie - the acting, the predictable plot - but I kept watching.  Before I knew it, I realized that I was hooked.  I passed on lunch when my boyfriend ask, I wanted to see how this movie played out.  All of a sudden, the over acting (not every actor) was fun, the plot was enjoyable, and I wanted to see how it was going to wrap up.

Yeah, the ending was kind of predictable, but I still loved it.  For once, a movie with dogs with no abuse, no dying, and although the story was corny, I loved it and I thought it was fun.  I doubt that I'm the target demographic (kids), but I think dog lovers would get a kick out of it.

It doesn't get 5 stars, but I think it deserves 4 stars from me, because this movie did what I needed; it provided a fun distraction and allowed me a break from my business (much needed).

If you love dogs like me, then you'll love "Wiener Dog Nationals". This movie is about a little boy named Danny, that dreams of being like his mom, a champion of the Wiener Dog Nationals. He ends up fulfilling that dream finding out that he can do what he wants do if he sets his mind to it.

In this movie, it's Danny's birthday and the one thing he wants for his birthday is a Wiener dog (dachshund). At first, his dad is not too happy about the idea because he knows that taking care of a dog is a lot of responsibility. The dad ends up saying that it's ok to get a dog and they do get a dog. They name her Shelly and she has a very special marking on her hind leg. It's a lightning bolt. Noone really knows what it stands for, but they think that it's cool. Danny enters her into the competition without their dad knowing. They go to the first race and Shelly makes it into the regionals. The problem is that they have to go to Indiana. They tell their dad and he says that they have to take her out of the competition. Then, he realizes that he was wrong and asks to get back into it. There are some problems at first but then she gets back into the Regionals, gets third place and they realize that the owner of the winning dog cheated so she was still in second place. Then the other dog, Handshake, passes the limit of the race. Therefore, Shelly wins the race. The main characters in this movie are Melanie (Alicia Witt), Judge Brown (Bryan Batt), Danny Jack (Julian Feder), Skip Jack (Austin Anderson), Phil Jack (Jason London), and Bridget (Caitlin Carmicheal).

What I like about this movie is that Danny loves his dog so much and that he has people there to support him. My favorite part is when Mrs. Merrywhether gets disqualified because she was playing an unfair game and then Shelly wins the race. There are no parts that I dislike because this movie was great and I really loved everything about it. I recommend this movie to ages 5 to 18, to people that love dogs and to people that help each other. Even though you are competing against some one, it doesn't mean that you have to be rude to each other. Reviewed by Valdi B KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. For more film reviews, go to kidsfirst.org

I was excited about this movie because I love dachshunds.  But the movie was spooty and obviously a low budget film.  For example; Rather than hire extras for the race scenes, they had the actors say "There are so many people here."  When there was only about 10 people.  And quite frankly...They just didn't show enough weenees for me.
Congress should pass a law that family movies like this are the only thing Hollywood can produce. No smut, no violence, no glorifying of the culture of violence. Highly recommend.

Had potential to be good movie, however acting was cheesy, not nearly enough footage with the dogs or the actual races and some major flaws...foot has bandage on front leg and the next scene it's on the back? COME ON!  Glad I rented vs buying it.

The writing, acting, and editing are pretty bad, even for a totally predictable kid's movie.  Way too much talky drama as a Spielbergian dysfunctional family takes up wiener dog racing while coping with the death of the mother.  Unnecessary side plot involving a scammer hawking a muscle spray.  Morgan Fairchild gives the only half-decent performance among the cast, playing a two-dimensional stereotypical rich bitch dog racer who coddles her showdog and ignores her daughter.  If you're into dachshunds or actual wiener dog races, you'll be disappointed, as the race scenes are very brief and they just cut to the outcome with very few shots of the dogs actually running.  To end on a positive note, at least this movie is rated G and free of the fart jokes, toilet humor, and endless pop culture references that plague most family/kid movies.  There wasn't even a single use of "wiener" in an innuendo.
Great family movie.  It has a few ooops shots that slipped thru the final cut but still good.  All doxie owners and animal lovers will enjoy it.

This movie is ridiculously awful. I can only imagine that the people who rated this 4 stars ordered it for children and didn't actually watch it. The acting is terrible. The story is nonsensical and competely unrealistic. The cute dogs had little screen time and no tricks. I was forced to watch it because I let my kids choose the Movie night title. If I had paid for it I would want my movie back. This movie should be classified as cruel and unusual punishment or reserved for forcing confessions.
